Title: Convergence of $\sqrt{n}x_{n}$ where $x_{n+1} = \sin(x_{n})$
Content: Consider the sequence defined as $x_1 = 1$ $x_{n+1} = \sin x_n$ I think I was able to show that the sequence $\sqrt{n} x_{n}$ converges to $\sqrt{3}$ by a tedious elementary method which I wasn't too happy about. (I think I did this by showing that $\sqrt{\frac{3}{n+1}} < x_{n} < \sqrt{\frac{3}{n}}$, don't remember exactly) This looks like it should be a standard problem. Does anyone know a simple (and preferably elementary) proof for the fact that the sequence $\sqrt{n}x_{n}$ converges to $\sqrt{3}$?
AcceptedAnswer:
Before getting into the details, let me say: The ideas I'm talking about, including this exact example, can be found in chapter 8 of Asymptotic Methods in Analysis (second edition), by N. G. de Bruijn. This is a really superb book, and I recommend it to anyone who wants to learn how to approximate quantities in "calculus-like" settings. (If you want to do approximation in combinatorial settings, I recommend Chapter 9 of Concrete Mathematics .) Also, this isn't just about $\sin$. Let $f$ be a function with $f(0)=0$ and $0 \leq f(u) < u$ for $u$ in $(0,c]$ then the sequence $x_n:=f(f(f(\cdots f(c)\cdots)$ approaches $0$. If $f(u)=u-a u^{k+1} + O(u^{k+2})$ (with $a>0$) then $x_n \approx \alpha n^{-1/k}$ and you can prove that by the same methods here. Having said that, the answer to your question. On $[0,1]$, we have
$$\sin x=x-x^3/6+O(x^5).$$
Setting $y_n=1/x_n^2$, we have
$$1/x_{n+1}^2 = x_n^{-2} \left(1-x_n^2/6+O(x_n^4) \right)^{-2} =  1/x_n^2 + 1/3 + O(x_n^2)$$
so
$$y_{n+1} = y_n + 1/3 + O(y_n^{-1}).$$ We see that
$$y_n = \frac{n}{3} + O\left( \sum_{k=1}^n y_k^{-1} \right)$$
and
$$\frac{1}{n}y_n = \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{n} O\left( \sum_{k=1}^n y_k^{-1} \right)$$
Since we already know that $x_n \to 0$, we know that $y_n^{-1} \to 0$, so the average goes to zero and we get $\lim_{n \to \infty} y_n/n=1/3$. Transforming back to $\sqrt{n} x_n$ now follows by the continuity of $1/\sqrt{t}$.
